--- In SHQ@yahoogroups.com, "warg3791" <Warg3791@a...> wrote:
> Yes Tetsu and Tatsu were both real. And Tetsu really was 
Hijikata's 
> page. However, they did not join the Shinsengumi until 1867. I 
think 
> Tatsu left the group after either Toba-Fushimi? Or Was it Kofu? 
But 
> Tetsu followed Hijikata all the way to Hakodate, Ezo (Hokkaido).

Probably it is Goheishinden or Nagareyama that Tatsu escaped. After 
that, he returned to the hometown and became a merchant. He died of 
an illness in Meiji 5. However, his posterity exists. 


> During this time Hijikata finished settling things about him. On 
May 
> 5, 1869 he gave several items (a letter, the picture of him, a 
sword, 
> and I think a poem?) to Tetsu and ordered him to get out of 
Hakodate 
> and take these things to his family. 

Tetsu is not sending the sword to Hino. This is the fact which many 
Japanese Shinsengumi fans' people also misunderstand. I also thought 
that Tetsu sent the sword to Hino. It is only Hijikata's photograph 
and letter which Tetsu sent. It is the fiction of "Moeyo ken" of 
Shiba Ryotaro that Tetsu sent the sword. Kanesada which Hijikata's 
posterity has is the sword which it left to the Hijikata family, 
when he goes to Kofu. 

momoiro-usagi
